reviewText: "Noah" is a big budget film that wants to desperately shoot new life into the famed biblical story. Artistic license is common in almost all bible to film endeavors, but "Noah" ruins itself with poor artistic interpretation. The idea of using walking rocks (that are very ineffective looking on screen) with a core of inner light to aid Noah was a creative disaster.  The "giants of old" from the biblical text  helping Noah build an ark was wise, but making them visually silly hurt the film.Be advised, some spoilers to follow. No one else should ever have been in the ark but Noah and his family, nor should they have been allowed to speak such terrible dialogue. I yearned to see a true survival story inside the ark, but again a forced new vision sidetracked a binding family. The movie is a lot of fluff with the weakest of scripts, that makes you want to just see the flood scene and get it over with.How many times does the "you were chosen" teaching mantra need to be said or implied in a film in which we know that is the needed formula? There are other ways to communicate that fact without actually saying it several times. It's worn out! I also didn't see most of the actors put an original stamp on their portrayals. Russell Crowe especially seemed to be doing his "Gladiator" character all over again.I'm done with Anthony Hopkins as the wise sage or father figure time and again in films. The character of Methusula could easily have been depicted with much more wisdom as well. Jennifer Connelly and Emma Watson were very good, and held together what vestiges of the film that were effective together.I was disappointed in the CGI. The animals entering the ark seemed utterly unreal,and earthly animals at the least should seem genuine. The flood itself was a bit of a bore. Water coming up from the earth was just wrong. Apart from some small moments of interests the movie is destined to be forgotten with its achingly old script, poor reimaginings and flat ending. Yes, a downer of a theatrical experience for a subject that had exceedingly more potential.Note: It turns out that water coming up from the earth actually occurred in the biblical account. Some astute Amazon users that commented on my review pointed that out. I was in error. As one  commentator said, "its one of the few things that  the film got right", and I agree, but a couple of Genesis accuracies can't save the film.

reviewText: Expectations are everything. I believe that the plan to produce such a movie was flawed right from the start. The biblical story of Noah is not very long, and its moral and practical message is pretty straightforward, in the Bible. Yet this movie made the attempt to stretch the story to 2 hours, so it added so many extra facets that kept us saying, "Wait, that's not in the Bible. What happened? Why is Noah doing this or that?" To make it worse, the moral message was watered down because it was expanded to include other moral quagmires. How the audience feels about these other moral decisions greatly affects their eventual opinion of the movie, and I don't think it will be good. Another sore point with me is that there really is no story climax---the plot just fizzles out towards the end. Main character Noah (Russell Crowe) might have a moral directive from God, but in his dedication to that he winds up doing some immoral stuff. How should we feel about him? He was supposed to be our hero. Noah's wife Jennifer Connelly, to her credit, does a fantastic acting job, especially her hateful rant towards the end. She delivers her lines so well that we are convinced that they spell the end of a relationship. But no, that is not what happens. Oh, God. And Anthony Hopkins: why is he in this movie in a role worth 10% of what he can deliver? Bad casting decision. Did he need the money badly, or was he chosen just for the name? And Ray Winstone as a savage leader? His acting persona is his face, his accent, and his erudite delivery. But here he is just slightly above the animals! One big plus for this movie is the gorgeous cinematography and special effects. In my view, the REAL star of the show were the stone-ash-crippled creatures called the Watchers. Very innovative, unlike any other creatures in movies. So, overall, I was disappointed with this film that went round-and-round towards the purported goal, which turned out to be anti-climactic when we got there. I say, bring back the Watchers and dump everybody else in this movie !!!

reviewText: The following review consists mainly of my own opinions and may contain spoilers. Caution.There's no way around it: Whether you're a Christian or Atheist, Noah is more than a little likely to severely offend you. I already knew that the account of Noah in this movie would be a bit different but there are liberties taken here that are arguably  blasphemous to the extreme. In this film "The Creator" AKA GOD is portrayed as a cruel, unforgiving and even indecisive being. The title character himself acts like a psychopath when he talks about murdering the children of his adopted daughter. At one point in the movie Noah even goes so far to say that the point of the flood and the ark is to make sure that ALL mankind is wiped out. If you believe in this account as historical fact, then that's not just silly, it's just plain wrong.I'd like to point out that there were many things in this movie that conflict with the Biblical account of Noah. For one, the Nephilim were the offspring of rebellious angels who came to Earth when they had relations with women. They were NOT benevolent Rock monsters! Most importantly though, was the fact that in the Bible, Noah and his family tried to warn everyone of the impending flood. Instead of listening however they just went on their merry way. Noah did NOT let those people die, the people on Earth had a choice to listen to Noah's warning or just die in the cataclysm. Part of Noah's assignment was to try and save any potentially righteous people! Oh, and because of the friendly rock monsters(Not Nephilim), it no longer takes Noah decades to build the ark, but only a few years. Oh and by the way, the Ark had a stowaway too. It says right there in Matthew 24:39 "and they took no note until the Flood came and swept them all away". Nobody tried to take the ark! Like I said, I was not nave enough to believe the account wouldn't be changed to some degree, but if this movie didn't take itself so seriously, it might come off as a comedy.The movie doesn't even pass muster as entertainment. It's tedious, it's hard to watch, it's just a very unpleasant experience because the story is basically pointless. Save the animals? Why? It's very hard for us the audience to identify with Noah in this movie. By the way, where in the bible did it say he let a girl caught in a bear trap that his one son loved die? At the end, Noah shamefully steals a verse from the Bible about being fruitful and filling the Earth. I guess that goes against what he said earlier about mankind dying out and the flood, or not? I don't know. Does this movie really need to be confusing in addition to being as indecisive as the creator is portrayed in this movie?The long and short is this: Noah the movie is garbage. These days when too few people even read the bible, most people are likely to see this film and they're not going to feel the least bit compelled to pick up the Bible. Movies like this in contrast to movies like the Ten Commandments or even The Passion of the Christ are likely to turn people off to the word of God. With a movie like this, there is a certain promise that the makers of the film should at least be somewhat faithful to the source material. But they couldn't even manage that. We can't really identify with anybody in the movie! Therefore a genuine emotional connection is lacking. Most women might even find it very hard to identify with Noah's wife, who is there just to stand there and look emotional throughout the whole thing. With such a drastic retelling, what was the point of the film? Since it deviates on such a ridiculous level from the original story with all sorts of stupid stuff added in(like the shedded snake skin thing), I can only conclude there was no point to the movie. Movies based on the bible should make you want to pick up the Bible. Unless you picked it up out of burning anger for what this movie did, did the movie really make you want to read the bible?Oh, and why are Atheists likely to be offended by this film? Because the movie asserts that God created the heavens and the earth, but it takes the rather dubious creationist point of view that the Earth was created in six literal days. No matter who you are, I can't imagine anyone watching this movie without feeling a bit sickened by the experience.
summary: I knew Hollywood was going to take some artistic liberties but... ROCK MONSTERS?!

reviewText: Normally I go easy reviewing Bible-based films. They are generally meant to appeal to a faith-based audience and often eschew great filmmaking for the sake of the message. All well and good. But Noah is not a Bible film. It is a political statement barely hidden behind one-dimensional, stereotyped characters within a loose retelling of a story from Hebrew Scriptures. If PETA and the EPA had written Genesis, this would be it. I have no problem with political movies per se, but don't try to tell us they are "Biblical". In this case the mischaracterization is a fraud and a sham. Where to begin?Noah and his family represent the flower children of the 1960s, nature's darlings, who consider it wicked to pluck even a petal. Everyone else on earth belongs to the damned. Why? Because they eat meat, practice deforestation, and believe that humans were given dominion over the world. For these reasons, humans are the vile, wicked occupants of planet Earth unworthy of God's redemption. Confused, I took a glance at my copy of the Torah. It seems to provide kosher methods for slaughtering animals for both eating and sacrificing, rules for eating the lambs on Passover, and God telling Adam and Eve to "be fertile...master the earth...and rule the fish, birds, and all living things" (Gen 1:28). I guess those centuries of Israelites who wrote and followed the very texts that this story is based on got it wrong. Fortunately, Hollywood knows better. By the way, don't forget, God originally planned to wipe out the animals, too (Gen 6:7).The political platform of this film manages to include jibes against hunters (girl gets caught in a steel bear trap - wonder how they had that in this pre-Iron Age world?), "bitter clingers" (Ham wants to keep the weapon given to him by the evil king against Noah's wishes), right-to-lifers (Na'el wants to keep her babies but Noah decides that infanticide is preferable to allowing the human race to continue). In fact, everything about this film bludgeons the point home that humans are bad, Creation is good. If only we would leave, the universe would once again be in balance. I'm no preacher, but I don't think that's the message of the Bible. Even Darwin's theory of evolution (in the midst of a Creationist account of the origins of life!) is championed here."Noah" is filled with the usual hypocrisy that accompanies political rants like this one. Though evil humans have deforested their land to build their vile city, Noah immediately proceeds to do the same and deforest the magic land grown from the seed of Eden to build his ark. Noah condemns his wife Naameh for admitting she would kill in order to protect her children (vile woman!) while Noah energetically kills any who would jump aboard his precious ark to save their lives. Ham is vilified by Noah for his sinful lust when all he wants is a wife to take with him to their depopulated future. He does not get one (according to Genesis, all the sons had wives). Noah (played with excruciating dullness by Russell Crowe who is once again stuck in first gear) gives a soliloquy against violence during a visual montage of warriors past and present (including, look closely, Revolutionary War-era and World War II-era soldiers). How evil! Never mind that some soldiers in history have actually fought to defend liberty and deny tyranny. I guess we should have let those nasty Nazis have their way.Artistic liberties abound as is generally unavoidable when making full-length motion pictures from often very little textual material. Nevertheless, the outright convolution of elements from inside and outside the Bible is astounding. In this film, the Tolkienesque Watchers, described in the book of Enoch and apparently equivalent to the "sons of God" of Gen 6:2, are good guys! The film presents them as angels who have come to help mankind (so far so good) until men duplicitously turned against them. In reality, the text of Enoch characterizes Watchers as "fallen" angels, i.e. demons, because when they got here they started lusting after human women, mating with them, and teaching humans about weaponry, sorcery, etc. Poor, misunderstood demons. They're so noble in this film, however, that they even build and defend Noah's ark.Methuselah, Noah's grandfather, played by the ubiquitous Anthony Hopkins, is a looney Gandalf-type character who lives in a cave, dreams of berries, and dispenses magic (sorcery?) whenever importuned. Women fair surprisingly poorly in such a liberal environment. They generally look on and weep and are ineffectual at anything they try. Naameh, played by Jennifer Connelley, gets one scene in which she unloads on cruel Noah but to no avail.The dour, depressing, soulless character of this film is not in any way reprieved by its brief five-minute attempt to rectify everything at the end. Noah realizes he cannot kill his grandbabies (hooray for him) and a rainbow appears in the sky. It's as if the studio, after seeing this monstrosity, begged the filmmakers for a happy ending no matter the inconsistency. Of course, anyone seeking religion from Hollywood is already misguided. Nevertheless, there is no inspiration here of any kind, religious or otherwise. It's just dreadful. If I want a religious movie, I'll stick with the Ten Commandments or Ben-Hur until something better comes along. If I want Tolkein, I'll go to the source.
summary: The Politics of "Noah"; or The Bible meets the Lord of the Rings

reviewText: The first biblical epic made by Hollywood in many decades isn't too faithful to its source: the presence of Stone giants should be a clue to that. Noah (Russell Crowe) is, in modern parlance, a quite fanatical environmentalist. Not only he is a vegetarian, but he reproaches his son when he picks up a flower. You see, he only eats those fruits and vegetables that had already fallen to the ground (such extreme ethics won't impede him from killing scores of men if it needs be). His family of gatherers stands in contrast with the mean men living in the dirty proto industrial cities, places where sin and disobedience to God (or the Creator, as the movie calls him) rules. That Noah values animals over men is seen by his ultimate plan (which he claims has been dictated to him by the Creator): he wants humanity to become extinct after the flood. That's why when he learns that his daughter (Emma Watson) is pregnant, he vows to kill her baby if it turns out to be a girl, as he wants the survivors of the flood to be the last humans on Earth. Criticism aside one must admit this is a generally well made, compelling and entertaining movie. Anthony Hopkins has a nice cameo as Methuselah, who is portrayed here as an ancient Gandalf like wizard (the Lord of the Rings seems to have been as much as an influence on this movie as the Bible here). Ray Winstone is fine as the chief Bad guy, the king of the evil men Tubal Cain. Also with Jennifer Connelly as Noah's wife. The barren locations (mostly in Iceland) help.
summary: Nor perfect but entertaining

reviewText: ~this review was written after seeing the film in the theaters on opening night~Finding a place to begin a review of ‘Noah’ is difficult for me.  I have so many things to say about this and yet knowing where to start is hard to pinpoint.  I could just ramble from the get-go and eventually get to a place where it all makes sense and it all comes together and yet I’m not even sure that that would happen since at the moment I’m still processing everything and trying to formulate my actual opinion.  Maybe finding a place to start is not the problem at all, but finding the TIME to start.  I mean, is now really the best time to flesh out a review of the film you just saw, or would it be more appropriate to wait until I’ve had the needed days to process?  I’ve asked myself this question all day long, as I’ve continued to tweet various feelings about the film or post paragraphs about it on various social mediums.The bottom line is that I can’t stop thinking about it and so maybe now is the best time to write this all down.I’ll be pretty up front in admitting that ‘Noah’ was one of the films I was most looking forward to this year.  In fact, ever since the project was announced with Aronofsky at the helm and Crowe in the lead I was hooked.  I’ve been waiting with wide eyed anticipation since early last year.  But then harmful speculation started to sneak into the media and the idea that Aronofsky’s Biblical epic was indeed a disaster began to take root.Everyone’s a critic, right?There are many ways to look at a film like ‘Noah’.  I think this is where many people are going to find themselves either on the outside looking in, are settled into the front seat, awaiting the ride.  The Bible is a very tricky subject, because the passion surrounding it is heated from both sides.  Those who follow it as the book of God don’t like it to be messed with, and those who view it as a man’s book consider its contents ridiculous, outdated and irritating.  You cannot please both camps.  Darren Aronofsky has flirted with God, faith and the paranormal before, and so this isn’t exactly new territory for him.  Many note ‘The Fountain’ as an example of Aronofsky’s delving into faith, and many also note that film as a reason why he should stay away from the subject.I happen to think that film has lofty ideas and a great sense of originality, but it needed a little more guidance.‘Noah’ works, for me at least, as a separate entity, removed from its source.  The film veers so much from the written text that anyone watching it an expecting an exact retelling of the preserved story is going to find themselves confused.  Aronofsky alters many well-known aspects of Noah’s story (including his depiction of the fallen angels, here seen as kind hearted ‘watchers’, cursed to the Earth for their desire to help men right themselves with The Creator) and so some (or many) Christians may have a hard time swallowing this particular version of Noah’s story.  I have to admit, the Christian in me was slightly alarmed by these alterations, and there were a few individuals at the showing I attended to walked out during a key scene between Noah’s rival, Tobal-Cain, and Noah’s son Ham.  Still, there is something that I continue to come back to that makes this film feel all the more important to me.The bottom line is that ‘Noah’ serves as a wickedly astute allegory to modern man’s struggle with faith.  Much less a Biblical, historical account, Aronofsky’s Noah is a marvelous depiction of the modern man and his eternal plight to understand, and account, before God (or whatever being he puts faith in).  Instead of delivering to us a film that feels like a dusty historical account, complete with technical authenticity, Aronofsky brings Noah to the 21st Century, giving him the weight of modern man and making him emotionally accessible to his audience.  The themes that Aronofsky broaches here, from blind faith, doubt, self-righteousness, guilt and mercy all stem from a place that feels more suited to our modern society, thus giving this ‘telling’ a more arresting feel.I can completely understand why those who don’t like anything interfering with scripture will not appreciate this work, but separated from the text I think one should be able to appreciate how beautiful Aronofsky wove this tale.It doesn’t all work though.  There are some narrative issues, some plot construction issues that feel fractured from the rest of the film.  Still, these fractions are slim and don’t hamper the overall impact of the film.Anchoring this film is a pretty impressive performance by Russell Crowe, who carries so much weight in his eyes that he, in my eyes, becomes the ideal Noah for Aronofsky’s tale.  Watching his dissension into madness over his own internal struggle with faith, having his beliefs shaken by his observance of mankind and ultimately lose all his sanity in his plight to ‘do The Creator’s work’, is completely mind blowing.  Sadly, the rest of the cast doesn’t fare as well.  Emma Watson and Jennifer Connelly are somewhat uninteresting until the very end, when they cry a lot, and Douglas Booth does absolutely nothing to the point where I honesty wonder if a lot of his scenes were but.  Anthony Hopkins is just a cliché and a badly drawn one at that, and Leo McHugh Carroll (and honestly Gavin Casalegno as well) are so effeminate looking I thought for a moment that they changed the sex of Noah’s children.  Ray Winstone and Logan Lerman fair the best of the supporting cast thanks to the moral complexity of their characters, and Winstone’s muttering dispute with The Creator is telling to the state of Aronofsky’s Biblical world.Visually, this film is a treat.  The cinematography is absolutely stunning.  The mix of gritty lighting and harsh tones with that storybook scenery (and those night backdrops with shadows and crayon skies) is simply breathtaking.  The CGI doesn’t always work (especially when the animals are entering the ark) but the actual flood is breathtaking, and the use of CGI in a distanced effect (like the swarming birds) sends chills.  At the heart of this atmosphere is yet another stunning score by Clint Mansell, which builds to such heights over the course of the film.Darren Aronofsky’s ‘Noah’ is not your father’s Noah.  It’s not even your Noah, but it is a variation of the man who really was always the perfect canvas for the dissection of faith that Aronofsky attempts to debate.  Here is a man who was saddled with the weight of a worldwide destruction.  The impact of that foreknowledge is ripe for so many interpretations.  While one may argue that scripture should not be ‘interpreted’ at will, I don’t think that what Aronofsky does here alters the breadth of the scriptures but merely opens up the conversation for our own modern idea of faith.This is a heavily flawed film, but it is also a film that demands conversation, and the fact that the one thing I keep returning to is the film’s clear modern application makes me feel like this could be the one film from 2014 that we continue to return to and continue to debate.A flawed masterpiece is far better than a perfected failure.
summary: It’s going to be a wet one…

reviewText: Noah is the type of movie that should have been picked up by a director experienced with biblical epics, like Mel Gibson and his Icon Productions company. Those looking for a "Ben-Hur" will instead be treated to a stripped-down version of the book of Genesis, that is no different from other recent disaster movies, such as "2012."The cast can't hold this shipwrecked screenplay together. Jennifer Connelly single-handedly ruins the entire movie with her misplaced over-acting, pristine appearance, and general frailness. According to the book of Genesis, Noah lived around 5,000 BCE. Why does everybody in this movie look like they belong on the Scottish Lowlands with William Wallace? Moreover, why does Ray Winstone and his army lay siege to Noah's ark with welding masks covering their faces?For whatever reason, Darren decided to include "fallen angels" to watch over earth. These are nothing more than stone golems, taken straight from Peter Jackson's Hobbit films. Unlike better movies based on the Bible, Noah is devoid of religious undertones. This is a good trait in 99% of films, but not this one. Noah is a blatant LOTRO clone, and best viewed from a secular perspective.

reviewText: Now, I'm not going to say that "Noah" doesn't have it's problems, because it definitely does (pacing and some dialogue, to be specific). But despite that, it's still a well-made and thought-provoking film with incredible cinematography, fantastic acting, and immaculate sound design. The film begins as an epic fantasy movie and slowly transitions into a gripping psychological drama.To say this is one of Aronofsky's darker films is an understatement, but that may be one of the reasons why I loved it so much. In his version of the story, Noah becomes an extremely dark character who (through lack of communication) is unsure of God's wishes about whether or not the human race should survive after the flood. After witnessing the wickedness of man firsthand (trading young women for meat, ripping animals apart with their bare hands, etc.), Noah is horrified and although God does not contact him after the initial warning of the oncoming flood, Noah misinterprets God's silence as confirmation that He believes humans have done enough damage in this world and do not deserve a second chance.I'm not going to give anything else away for the sake of spoilers, but I insist you give this a watch. And whatever you do, don't listen to the Christian fundamentalists trying to tear this movie apart for inane reasons, like that it isn't "historically accurate" to the Bible. Guess what? Christians aren't the only one with a flood story. In fact, "Noah" was based on multiple religious texts including the Bible, Jewish mid-rashes and other Gnostic texts. Pretty much everything included in the film is based on something in some type of religious text - yes, even the "rock monsters" are Aronofsky's interpretation of the giants who are referenced in the Bible and other texts. So to say this film is inaccurate is one of the most ignorant things I can possibly think of and it's a pity that this ignorance has affected so many of the ratings here.
summary: Newsflash: Christians don't have a monopoly on the Noah story

reviewText: Noah is well-acted, intense, and visually it is beautiful from beginning to end, but WOW is the story wild.Creative license had to be taken with the story of Noah. Let's be real, the biblical account does not tell us much of anything in the realm of detail- that's all left up to the reader's imagination. Anyone making a movie about Noah and the ark is going to have to make some of it up out of necessity. But what Aronofsky did with Noah is on another level altogether.First, what the devil is with the Watchers? Aronofsky made these fallen angels from the apocryphal Book of Enoch an essential part of Noah's story, and it was confusing as hell. For starters, why are the Watchers giant rock monsters? These things are lifted almost straight out of Tolkien's Lord of the Rings (they look and fight almost exactly like the ents inThe Two Towers), and their existence and purpose are never sufficiently explained. Why are they there? They fell from heaven. Okay, but why are they giant rocks? And why do they hide? Oh, men are evil, turned on them, and persecuted them. BUT THEY'RE GIANT, 30-FOOT TALL ROCKS; they could destroy mankind easily, no? In any case, they're excruciatingly boring characters, and their inclusion in the film is just very awkward.Second, Noah experiences a personality change halfway through the film that feels quite unnatural. The loving Noah of the first half of the film, the good father and gentle husband, the Noah who took Ila in and raised her as his own daughter, disappears entirely. Suddenly, we have a Noah who turns a blind eye to violence and suffering. He gives his family the cold shoulder. Oh, and he threatens to kill newborns. I don't know if this was an attempt to portray the religious in a negative light or if it was just strange writing, but either way it came across as very forced and very out-of-character.Third, the whole film feels like a fairy tale. I was interested in a serious take on the story of Noah, a portrayal that could conceivably have happened in real life (with a fair bit of divine intervention, of course), not the stuff of a Disney fantasy. Even beyond the ridiculous Watchers, we're subjected to an overly dramatic account of creation, the hokey murder of Abel by his brother Cain, magic bright rocks that start fires, an evil stowaway on the ark, and, again, a Noah who practically becomes a serial killer. It's just too much to stomach.Fourth, the film's environmental message is not at all subtle. God had the world of men destroyed because they did not respect creation. All life is precious, nature is holy, and killing and eating animals is wrong. Yech! Spare me.Given these shortcomings, I am not at all surprised to read a fair amount of Christian outrage over this film. I myself am a Catholic, and while I don't fault Aronofsky for taking some liberties with the story of Noah and the Ark, I do fault him for making a mockery of it. While I did not think the movie was "bad" per se, I just did not enjoy it all that much, and I am also sympathetic to those who feel it has been misrepresented in trailers and advertisements. What you see is not what you get!Apart from a few powerful scenes (Noah attempting to console Ila was exceptional, as was his venture into the "enemy" camp), Noah is nothing more than pure entertainment: there are a lot of pretty visuals, great special effects, and a fair amount of action, but there is no overarching theme or deep moral message (unless you count "respect nature" as such). Noah missed every opportunity to make a profound statement about life or being human, which is really too bad. I also feel I should mention that Noah is pretty intense for a PG-13 film. Overt/graphic violence is not the issue here, but there are some very heavy, emotional scenes and a fair deal of implied nastiness, so you may want to think twice before bringing the whole family. All things considered, Noah is an okay film. I was just expecting something different, something a lot less weird.

reviewText: I think this is important to get straight right at the start: Darren Aronofsky's NOAH is not a purely Biblical epic. It is, instead, an artistic and personal film made by one of cinema's more commercial auteurs - who has managed to create his most compelling general audience film to date.So, while the plot moves in loose accordance with the Bible (which in actuality leaves many gaps in Noah's saga) director and co-writer Aronofsky filled in the rest, and in so doing has turned out a watchable 140-minute movie that keeps the audience, if not glued to their seats, at least tuned in. But be warned: if you demand religious "accuracy," this is not the film for you...the word "God" is never mentioned (Noah's mentor is instead referenced as "The Creator"), and Aronofsky is quite liberal when it comes to constructing a movie he feels is "inspired by" the Bible, rather than in strict unity with it.This becomes clear early on when angels plummet from heaven and become mired in the cooling lava of a newly forming earth, becoming rock-like (and also kinda spider-like) "watchers" who have the pretty unfortunate job of trying to keep mankind in line. We all know about Adam and Eve's really bad day in the Garden of Eden, but it is  years later, when their son Cain murders brother Abel, that Cain's genetic line becomes doomed, and his tainted offspring go about plundering the earth for all they can steal.And so it is up to Cain and Abel's kinder, gentler sibling Seth to give mankind its last chance -- a shaky one indeed, as his policy of non-confrontation soon places his lineage in risk of becoming extinct. An angry Creator soon has had enough, and gives Seth's last heir, Noah, the command to build an Ark in preparation for a civilization-ending flood.What Aronofsky does well is build a story that concerns itself with The Man Noah and the broad shoulders he must put to use carrying the burden of the Creator's request. There are several moving scenes that concern the immense yoke (and later, horror) of turning one's back upon the masses of people who at first demand, then beg to be saved. In addition, the very fact that Noah has been chosen as the conduit for the Creator is often questioned not only by those outside the family, but those within as well. Even Noah himself questions the Creator's reasons for selecting him, for who is to say what is meant by the cryptic messages he is sent in the form of bizarre dreams? It is in this regard that NOAH the movie is strongest, especially when portrayed by the extremely capable actor Russell Crowe.While I certainly liked NOAH, I don't think it is a movie I will sit through twice - at least not for quite a while. This is not to say it is not watchable -- for it is - nor is it meant to knock either Aronofsky's direction or the very capable acting of, in addition, Jennifer Connelly as wife Naameh and or Emma Watson as foster daughter Ila, as all three really empower the movie in superbly professional style. It's only that this is a movie burdened by its unleavened darkness. While one might combat such a critique with "Well, what else?", I only respond that there could have been more attention paid to the wonderment of such a task. From the creation of the Earth to its near destruction, from the creation of the Ark to the amazing arrival of the animals, two by two, and even the beaching of the Ark and the emergence of new life upon it, I kept looking for more moments to gasp in awe at the spectacle. I wanted to, but It. Just. Felt. So. Damned. HEAVY.I did feel some effort was made toward the presentation of the Ark early on: it was a massive construct of wood, surrounded by web-like scaffolds, and though we only see it at the end of its construction we are indeed treated to a few scenes within before the animals arrive. It was immense, and did a good job of making me feel that given a little artistic license this really could have been a vessel capable of the task. And when those creatures arrive we get a little peek at the surprise of Noah and his family at their appearing out of the woods, either slithering or crawling or trundling along. But I felt more like it just happened, rather than it being - well, spectacular. Frankly, they looked pretty CGI.But I was immensely pleased that, while Aronofsky seemed to allow for a metaphorical interpretation of the creation as a "Seven Day" process, he never shied away from promoting Evolution with a capital E (just as he seemed to cater to science for the creation of the planets). And the movie was ecologically minded as well, though in an obvious way: Noah's family were expressly forbidden to eat meat, for doing otherwise would obviously make EXTINCT any animal they chose. It was nice to see the movie emphasize the worth of the animals over the petty needs of our stomachs.All in all, I was glad I watched NOAH, and "carried" the film with me when I left the theater. It was more accessible than Aronofsky's previous fare: 2006'sThe Fountain, 2008'sThe Wrestler, and 2010'sBlack Swan(the last two of which were nominated for two and five Oscars, respectively).  I re-emphasize how impressed I was with how this movie seemed to be less about the Noah as a religious figure and more about this troubled, beleaguered man who was given an enormous task, and of his bearing that weight even while he repeatedly questioned not only what he must do, but WHY such an mammoth mission was given to HIM to bear. "Why me?" he asks repeatedly -- and this is a question all who survive must also determine for themselves. When at one point his interpretation of his visions causes a near mutiny, we can only ponder what might have happened had there been a collapse of the very family that was Mankind's only chance to re-populate the planet.See NOAH if A) you like a director unafraid to stick his neck out for the films he makes; B) you have wondered about the Great Flood but preferred to see the story from a thoughtful perspective rather than, say, Michael Bay's; and C) you are okay with an interpretation of one of the Bible's great tales that The Great Book itself never really "fleshed out."

reviewText: Darren Aronofsky, who was the director, a producer, and one of the two writers of this Noah movie, spun the Biblical story in some very weird directions.  I feel that the Noah's ark story's thematic power is seriously weakened by the worldview he projects on the script.  Though Aronofsky is an atheist, I am aware that John Huston, also an atheist, created a well-liked Biblical movie, called The Bible:  In the Beginning.  Thus I knew having an atheist direct it wouldn't necessarily make the movie irreverent.  I expected that seeing Noah in the theater would be an interesting experience, because I'd read quite a bit on the internet about the changes it makes from the Bible, but I hoped that I would at least find the themes satisfying.  In theory, they are, but I could not be more disappointed with how Aronofsky weakened them in his execution of the movie.Rather than listing the ways it departed from the Bible, my focus in reviewing it is to describe reasons I feel the changes weakened the movie:THE NOAH CHARACTERThe characterization of Noah as an almost psychopathic, duty-driven, misanthropic (anti-human) person is pessimistic, whereas the Bible, written from the Jewish perspective, presents the Noah story as a memorial of God's faithfulness to protect those who are righteous.  The Old Testament's theme is God's faithfulness.  (Genesis 8:1 says "But God remembered Noah" and caused the flood to cease.)  The movie could have included some great dialogue as they wait in the ark and try to be patient as the flood continues to go on for 40 days.  Instead, on this movie, Noah becomes demented on the ark, and everyone is trying to hide from him because he intends to kill off his family because he believes God hates people.  Instead of doing twisted psychological things like Aronofsky likes to do in movies, couldn't Aronofsky instead focus on themes of family and of thankfulness to God?  The whole movie is about Noah's confusion as to whether God likes people or not, and because Noah ultimately finds the goodness within his own instincts instead of from his understanding of God, it felt to me like a weak morality tale, even though the theme of valuing mercy over justice should, in theory, be a sure-fire success.  The reason the justice/mercy theme felt weak to me at the end is because the Noah character doesn't get any clarity from his understanding of God, nor thank God for preserving him from the flood.  God is the one who demonstrated a balance of justice (judgment) and mercy (protection) for people and for animals, yet in the movie, Noah finds that within himself, while believing he's failing God by showing mercy to his family.  That whole subplot of Noah wanting to kill his family because he believes God hates people doesn't even make sense, since he wouldn't have built the ark if he believed that.  It's the thing that weakens the script the most.Amazingly for a Biblical epic, God is almost made into the product of Noah's imagination, because instead of hearing from God, he has to interpret a wordless dream, and he becomes so blind to humane concerns because he believes God is all about destruction.  He somehow concludes at the end that God wants him to be fruitful and multiply, after getting drunk for feeling some guilt about sparing his family.  There's also a dysfunctional (doesn't fit with the story's theme(s)) subplot where Ham grows more distant from Noah because Noah didn't care about the girl Ham rescued from Tubal-cain's ruffians.  Ham wanders off by himself after the flood because he feels rejected--after the incident involving Noah's drunkenness, actually.  Ham growing distant from Noah doesn't tie into the theme at all, and I also really think a movie about Noah ought to end before the incident where he gets drunk, since it only was meaningful to the Jewish compilers because Noah curses Canaan, which would be the nation of Israel's enemy.NOAH'S FAMILY DOESN'T UNDERSTAND, EITHERThe character of Methuselah, a religious hermit in the movie, says Noah must interpret God's dream himself, and that it's not for him to tell Noah what's right and wrong.  It amazed me that all of these characters didn't have any confidence about who God was or assurance that God cares about people.  If someone is going to make a film about something so monumental as a great worldwide flood, which God caused and protected Noah from, then stop slowing down the story by dwelling on "Does God love people?" and focus on the process of preparing for the flood and on God's promise after the flood to never again destroy the world like that.  In the end, NOT ONE PERSON in his family speaks up to tell Noah that he misunderstood the mind of God, i.e., that God intended humans to survive.  After his instincts keep him from killing his family, he feels he's failed God, but no one tells him that God loves mercy.ANIMALS ARE SUPPOSEDLY ALWAYS GOODAronofsky was also unashamedly revisionist in making it so pro-animal but anti-human, to a laughable degree--as if everything NOT human is good, as if there's no such thing as animal predation.  In the movie, God's cause for destroying the world was that people ruined the soil and didn't care about endangered species and wanted to hunt instead of eat food they had grown.  But what about cruelty to other humans?  That's not shown very much, and when it is, it still is not emphasized as a reason for God to spare Noah but destroy the others.  The movie emphasized people's lack of ecology as the basis for God destroying the world.SUGGESTIONS OF WHAT SHOULD'VE BEEN DIFFERENTI have no problem with a somewhat ecological focus, but I feel the movie skewed the Noah story in weird enough ways that it became more like environmentalist screed than even a morality tale.  I read online that Emma Watson got sick from the water because ultra-green Aronofsky wouldn't let her have a plastic water bottle when filming on location in Iceland, and told her to live with her ill feelings and use 'em to make her acting more intense.  Instead of spending half an hour or more filling the movie with Noah's psychological tension, Aronofsky should've shown more of the process of building the ark (and without supernatural help--the movie adds stone giants called "Watchers" who help Noah out) and also Noah trying to warn the world to stop being licentious and irresponsible.  Instead of having Noah's family hide from him on the ark because he is waiting for the flood to end so he can kill his family, Aronofsky should've had them talk about God's faithfulness to protect them, and show more specifics of how life on the ark functioned.TWO OTHER SUBPLOTS THAT SHOULD'VE BEEN SCRAPPEDThe magic seed:  Another subplot that makes no sense is that Noah needs a magic seed from Methuselah in order to immediately grow a forest so he can have wood for the ark, because the entire land has been laid waste because of Tubal-cain.  As if it's possible in a world before huge factories and nuclear weapons to completely eliminate all life in entire regions?  Where are the rest of the sections of the world?  Is God going to destroy everything because Tubal-cain's settlement trashed a certain part of the planet?  And are the only people just Noah's small family and a settlement led by Tubal-cain?  There are plenty of other areas of the world which haven't been destroyed, yet humans as a whole are bad because Tubal-cain has an especially cavalier attitude about animal life and plants' ecosystems.  Noah himself doesn't show any concern in the movie about how to preserve those special kinds of trees after he cuts 'em down after using the magic seed to grow a forest.The snakeskin:  And what's with the snakeskin from the Devil being some kind of family heirloom?  Would you want to wear an evil artifact on you right after you get through the global flood?  So many plot points make no sense in this messed up movie!CASTINGAnthony Hopkins and Ray Winstone, playing Methuselah and Tubal-cain, respectively, gave me my few laughs in the movie.  Methuselah gets covered by a flood as he gets his last wish, to be satisfied with some berries which he was talking about from early on in the movie.  Tubal-cain has excellent swagger, and I found myself rooting for him some because I love Ray Winstone's acting.  Russell Crowe played the Noah character more darkly than anyone else could, which is what he was supposed to do, in keeping with the director's wishes.  Emma Watson as his daughter-in-law and Jennifer Connelly as his wife played their parts strongly.  The script was the problem, not the acting.

reviewText: Noah.  God.  The deluge to destroy the world and then start it anew.  A pair of every living creature housed within a vast ship made of "gopher wood."  Beyond the question of one's faith, it is hard to imagine a person not knowing this story or at least having a version of it in his or her head.  Here it is interpreted on film by director Darren Aronofsky (The Wrestler) as a mega-budget action/adventure spectacle and also as a meditation on, among other concerns, the environment and the concept of justice.  Russell Crowe is an able Noah:  ever a source of cinematic fury and grit, he can create this type of bearded monument to the macho and the mad with ease, though there is never a sense he is challenged despite the iconic nature of the role.  The overall result is ambitious and not without a certain objective interest in regard to its production and how it is received around the world, yet, as a film, as an intended entertainment, it is uneven and at times even unpleasant.Changes to the story as presented in Genesis, or rather details and tensions inserted to turn it into a feature-length film, have generated furious debate.  In my opinion, as an atheist who finds the story of Noah intriguing without believing it to be true in any way, shape, or form, a few of the changes are positive and a few are negative.  The worst:  the conception and inclusion of angels turned stone giants named the Watchers, beings who aid Noah's construction and engage in a brutal fight sequence as the flood begins.  These computer-generated monster-protectors play as if they tramped their way out of second-rate deleted scenes from the Lord of the Rings or Pirates of the Caribbean franchises, and I could never invest in their involvement in the storyline.  A more rewarding alteration:  Tubal-Cain, a smith (descended from the first murderer) briefly mentioned in the Bible, is played by Ray Winstone as a self-proclaimed king who refuses to be stamped out by the Creator to whom the stoic Noah is so beholden, at least not without a bone-crushing, throat-slicing fight.  The way his desperate urge toward self-preservation manifests itself is riveting, as is the way he contends with others or seduces them to his side.In general, aforementioned stone giants notwithstanding, this is a film which rouses in its large moments, but falls short in regard to more fundamental elements, including character development.  A scene in which Noah spins a campfire tale regarding God's creation of the universe results in a psychedelic time-lapse montage placing Adam and Eve within an evolutionary context, and the result is as gorgeous as it is provocative.  This is a bold and neat gambit.  Yet, on the other hand, consider Noah's sons, including Ham and Shem, and how thinly conceived they are.  They are important characters, yet there is not a single significant moment of interaction to reveal to the audience the ever-evolving dimension of love and resentment so often shared by brothers and sisters.  Portrayed by porcelain stud Douglas Booth, Shem in particular is a nonentity and cipher.  And so it goes with Noah the film:  amazing visuals and moments of rousing acting give way to hamstrung dramatic beats and underdeveloped characters and ideas.
summary: An ambiitous, but flawed epic by Aronofsky

reviewText: What to say about this movie that hasn't already been said before?  In the first hour or so, director Darren Aronofsky sets up an intriguing premise: that the entire idea of the flood is God's revenge on humankind for having destroyed the world.  There is a strong sense of contemporaneity about this message, especially when we consider issues such as global warming and environmentalism.  As Noah, Russell Crowe comes across as a convincing servant of the Creator, someone charged with the responsibility of implementing His word, yet unable to exercise free will.  Despite living a pious life, he has to preside over the destruction of a sinful world so that a New World might be created.  Noah's dilemma is obvious, especially when we observe the way in which he is concerned for his family's future, even the wayward son Ham (Logan Lenman).  As his grandfather Methuselah, Anthony Hopkins comes across as equally dedicated to the divine cause - despite living in comparative squalor, he finds enough to sustain himself in the earth, rather than having to rely on anyone.  Once the flood occurs - in a stunning sequence of special effects - the film falls apart: director Aronofsky seems less interested in exploring the consequences of human action, and the ways in which it can traduce God's word, as seen, for instance in the relationship between Noah and his perpetual adversary Tubal-cain (Ray Winstone, a plausibly tooth-gnashing villain), and resorts instead to a family melodrama involving Noah, his wife Naameh (Jennifer Connelly), his eldest son Shem (Douglas Booth) and adopted daughter Ila (Emma Watson).  The two leading actresses give performances that can most charitably be described as undistinguished, devoid of light and shade.  The film ends happily - for Noah's family, at least - with humankind re-assuming its position at the center of all activity.  According to Hollywood logic, it seems that even the Creator has to take a supporting role.

reviewText: Historical renditions can be a freighting topic to tackle in regards to getting the facts straight, especially when a writer/director is attempting to depict a specific series of events from the Bible.  Over the years, there have been multitudes of films portraying Moses and Jesus Christ – two prophets of God, both of whom play a prominent role in the Book of God.  There are several other individuals that are also supremely important to the Bible, yet individuals like David, Peter, or Paul, are apparently not provocative enough to warrant a big screen treatment.  In fact, it’s quite astonishing that it’s taken this long for a filmmaker to have the desire to create a feature about Noah and his ark.  Perhaps it’s simply a matter of writers and directors not wanting to deal with the abundance of controversy that accompanies these stories.  But, it’s obvious Darren Afronofsky is not a man that shies away from a project due to controversy.Directed by Darren Afronofsky (Black Swan, The Wrestler), Noah stars Russell Crowe as Noah, the final pre-flood Patriarch of God.  As a young boy, Noah witnessed the death of his father at the hands of a tyrant, leaving him as the only remaining descendant of Seth (the final son of Adam and Eve).  While the descendants of Cain (also son of Adam and Eve) pillaged and plundered the Earth, Noah remained devoted to his creator – eventually marrying his wife, Naameh (Jennifer Connelly) and having three sons, Shem (Douglas Booth), Ham (Logan Lerman), and, Japheth (Leo McHugh), while also taking in an adoptive daughter, Ila (Emma Watson).Noah begins having dreams, which he believes are messages from the creator – indications that a planet-wide cleansing will wash away all land-based life, leaving only a small remnant of the planet’s population.  These dreams prompt Noah to start construction on an ark that will be large enough to protect two of each of the world’s species (animals, reptiles, etc.) in order to repopulate the Earth after the great flood.  Noah and his family are aided by a group of giants, called the watchers – angels forced to live out their days on Earth after defying their creator, but the production of the giant ark gains the attention of the Tubal-cain (Ray Winstone), the so-called king of man.Naturally, there’s absolutely no need to give away too many details about the plot progression, since the majority of us already know full well how the story concludes.  Regardless, Noah takes on the typical three-chapter mannerism of storytelling, the first of which shows Noah interpreting his dreams and then moving his family to an area where the ark will be built.  This also brings in Anthony Hopkins’ character, Methuselah – Noah’s grandfather, who is established as the grand old wizard that has endless knowledge of seemingly everything, but works only in riddles and magic.  And, despite the fact that Hopkins’ role is limited to only a handful of scenes, he brings brief moments of humor and leaves an all-important lasting impression on the outcome of the film.The second stanza vastly incorporates the film’s villain, portrayed by the flawless efforts of Ray Winstone.  Although he is a commanding character to be sure, he’s not a traditional villain in the sense that he has evil intentions on the brain or in his heart.  In this particular case, he reacts in the same exact manner that the majority of humanity would react if a scenario like this were to happen today, and that’s simple:  survive by any means necessary.  But, when God has his mind made up and is dead-set on washing the world clean, do you really think the actions of one man stand a chance against a force that is so great that no one could ever fully understand?  Exactly.  Sorry, that’s not a spoiler – that’s just common sense.In the final act, copious amounts of drama take full command of this film.  Once aboard the well-constructed vessel, Noah must come to grips with the fact that all mankind must come to an end, and of course, that includes the lives of he and his family.  Naturally, news of that nature is bound to drive any man a little crazy, creating a slew of standout scenes for Russell Crowe and one particularly emotional scene that allows Jennifer Connelly to steal the show.  Emma Watson also takes full advantage of her scenes, proving that she’s grown into a fine young actress (and outgrown Harry Potter) with enough potential to fill her shelves with an endless amount of shiny Hollywood awards – assuming she decides to get serious and take the right roles.Clearly, the casting choices for Noah worked out to the film’s benefit.  Still, the CGI elements are far more worthy of conversation than the acting.  But, like any massive Hollywood production, you can’t create an apocalyptic epic without blanketing the screen with special efforts.  While the book of Genesis does mention giants, it doesn’t go into the amount of detail that Aronofsky implements with his rock creatures – which are undeniably similar to Transformers.  If you don’t like staying through the credits, the voices of those rock creatures will sound familiar – voiced notably by Nick Nolte and Frank Langella.Overall, Noah is a grand experiment that can easily be best described as an ambitious epic with only the best of intentions.  Sadly, not everyone is going to see this film in the same light as writer and director Darren Aronofsky.  The oversized $150 million (in that ballpark) budget sets the bar high for a production that I fear will have disappointing returns, not because it’s poorly structured, badly written, or any of the usual reasons movies fail.  Big name actors like Russell Crowe, Anthony Hopkins, and Emma Watson are a welcome sight in a risky endeavor such as this, yet the polarizing subject matter vastly overshadows the terrific acting and stellar visuals.  Will you enjoy Noah?  That seems to be the question on everyone’s mind, so the best way to answer that question is to encourage you to take the risk and lend your time to a beautifully constructed feature and try to keep an open mind that it is a Hollywood production and not a minute-by-minute literal depiction.GRADE:  B+FNDNreview.com

reviewText: There's been a LOT of noise made about Darren Aronofsky's rather progressive interpretation of the biblical tale of NOAH, primarily from pundits over at Fox News, the citizens of GlennBeckistan and the Religious Right. Now it's clear from some of the reviews that some of the nay-sayers of this film CLEARLY went to this film to complain about it, or just didn't go to see it at all and are parrotting what they've read about the film. Complaining about not mentioning God (instead, to not alienate people of other faiths, they used the term "Creator" which was the term used for God in those days), to the "socialist progressive undercurrent" of the film (which doesn't exist), or that Noah is portrayed as a flawed, angry and violent human man as oppossed to the friendly "Let's get two of every animal and build an ark and have a happy time" children's picture-book telling of the tale.But what are you really expecting from the director of PI (super-indie B&W; film), REQUIEM FOR A DREAM (Major Indie drug addiction Depress-o-thon), THE FOUNTAIN (ultra-high-concept sci-fi art film), and BLACK SWAN (psychosexual hallucinatory thriller)?!??!? Aronofsky is an auteur. He's not a journeyman director. He's going to take whatever story interests and excites him and put his own spin on it.NOAH is not perfect. It's a somewhat flawed film with an epic scale that is, per usual of Aronofsky, visually arresting. Russell Crowe doesn't quite fit into this role as easily as he might have in the past, and Jennifer Connelly, despite being a great actress, feels a little stilted. Emma Watson is fitting into her post-HARRY POTTER career quite nicely in this film as well as work in films like MY WEEK WITH MARILYN and THE BLING RING. Ray Winstone is a little over-the-top here, but kind of fun to watch, and Anthony Hopkins is decidedly under-the-top yet again in a role that solely demands expository dialogue.However, the performances seem perfunctory to the visual tale that Aronofsky is telling. He wanted to tell this tale on the scale of the biblical tales of Cecil B. Demille, just without the all-ages stamp and all-star casting that caused people to flock to see THE TEN COMMANDMENTS, but most specifically, he wanted to tell a story that didn't have to adhere to every single sentence in the Bible. As with most of the Bible (and here comes the hate-mail), this is a story subject to interpretation, and his visual interpretation of this film is terrifically exciting. Although one would ask if Aronofsky was just making a film that not only was his vision, but was also to kind of troll the devout Christians. I would bet on mostly the former, and perhaps a little of the latter.Although, that just won't cut it in this day and age. I was hoping that we would have evolved as audiences since 1988, and the firey, hateful rhetoric caused by Martin Scorsese's absolutely brilliant LAST TEMPTATION OF CHRIST, but as reaction to this film has proven that we really haven't. Many people don't want "interpretations" of biblical stories; they want their biblical stories to be treated as totally literal with no room for interpretation. No critical thinking; no questioning.Makes you wonder what kind of God they're worshipping, or what some churches are teaching. I went to eight years of Sunday School (although that ended about 27 years ago, when I was confirmed), but the teachers never said "This is TRUTH, and to deny that is a sin!". They taught us that knowledge of truth and having faith CAN go hand in hand, but don't ALWAYS have to.

reviewText: There are scores of fables throughout the world that describe an apocalyptic flood with a lone survivor who repopulates Earth. From the Seminoles to the Senegalese, from the Mayan to the Malaysian, from the Inuit to the Egyptian, these are passed down through the ages with spooky similarities.As this movie began, it occurred to me that some of the kerfuffle from the fundamentalists might have been avoided if writer/director Darren Aronofsky had used something other than the Judeo-Christian version for inspiration. Then I realized he used the familiar names as a sort of shorthand to avoid the need for lengthy explanation. No matter what his rationale, by the time I left the theater, I felt I had been taken through all of Genesis (with generous doses of artistic license: the animals are computer generated images with only a slight tip of the hat toward realism). Do NOT trouble yourself with this film if you believe in a literal interpretation of the Judeo-Christian Bible.You see:* Russell Crowe ("Winter's Tale") as Noah, the paterfamilias who gets one upsetting message after another from The Creator. He's doing his best to obey; it is clear that he is the world's first conservationist.* Jennifer Connelly ("The Dilemma") as his wife Naameh, who seems part loving wife and mother, and part shaman (she paces through the ark swinging a sort of incense burner which anesthetizes the creatures).* Anthony Hopkins ("RED 2") is Methuselah (see, I told you "familiar names"), sitting on his mountain, who wants to enjoy the taste of berries one more time.* Logan Lerman ("Percy Jackson" franchise) does some of the heavy lifting as Ham, who asks the obvious question, "Where will I find a wife if all of mankind is wiped out?"* Emma Watson ("The Perks of Being a Wallflower") is Ila, their adopted daughter, gravely wounded when she was a child.* Douglas Booth ("Romeo and Juliet") is Shem, the lucky son who gets the girl.* Ray Winstone ("Hugo") is Tubal-Cain a descendant of Cain, perpetrator of the world's first fratricide. He says "I am a Man" and knows he has dominion over the animals.This PG-13 movie tries to cover too many issues and relies on computer generated imaging (rock warriors, anyone?) for all of the action. In my opinion, this only detracts from a fairly involving story, if only they had focused on it. Connelly, Crowe and Lehrman are all three very capable actors, so they brought more to the table than this script deserved.I saw this in a theater with closed captions. I suspect I would have missed some of the dialogue if I hadn't worn the glasses. There were some very quiet, murmured moments. I'm sure the DVD will have subtitles when Amazon releases it.

reviewText: ***This review may contain spoilers.”Not just Darren Aronofsky, director of “Noah”, but practically all directors and movie industry members attempting to bring Biblical stories to the screen walk a tightrope tethered between “faithful authenticity” and “rousing enjoyment”.  Usually, in my opinion, movie creators cave in to religious authenticity in their fearful desire to attract and placate both truly and sanctimoniously devout people at the risk of turning out a bland, lifeless, predictable product.  These movie creators seem to concede that it’s just too damn hard to create both a respectful and exciting epic.  I argue that Aronofsky has succeeded in doing just that in “Noah”, and he’s an atheist to boot!The basic structure and components of the Old Testament mythological “Noah and the Flood” are largely intact.  Granted, the tale itself is relatively straightforward and skeletal, but this works to Aronofsky’s advantage because he can introduce various subplots and previously peripheral characters to flesh out and fortify the story and make it really feel like an epic without mangling the story beyond recognition.  As I see them, these are the steps Aronofsky took to achieve this:1) As other Amazon reviewers have noted, Aronofsky has taken a Tolkeinesque approach to this material, including showing desolate wastelands, fantastic characters, miraculous events, and a daunting quest from a supernatural figure called the Creator.2) Making Noah (Russell Crowe), a man charged by the Creator with saving the non-human world from an impending flood, not only a devout, Creator-heeding and family-loving man, but also a virile, resolute man of action who will do just about anything to carry out his divine mission.3) In a slight but not fatal deviation from the text, “Noah” introduces a subplot involving Noah’s second-oldest son Ham’s (Logan Lerman’s) struggle with asserting his manhood and avoiding a lonely bachelorhood.4) Introducing the misshapen Watchers (who look like Transformers with a granite exo-skeleton), who ARE referenced in the Bible, as former angels cast from Heaven for aiding sinful humanity (how Promethean!) and condemned to wear a rocky skin.  Despite their ordeal, several Watchers agree to help Noah with building the ark to carry the world’s animals and protecting the vessel from the rest of humanity.  No matter what you think, it’s an imaginative, impressive way of explaining how Noah and only a few family members could fashion and preserve such a colossal vessel.5) Including the aged but still lively patriarch Methuselah (Anthony Hopkins), Noah’s grandfather, who gives his sometimes confused grandson sage advice and moral support, and even aids Noah’s daughter-in-law and son Shem’s (Douglas Booth’s) wife Ila (Emma Watson) with a troubling family problem.  And in return, all Methuselah asks is to satisfy a berry jones.6) Adding the character of Tubal-cain (Ray Winstone), a ferociously warlike (and carnivorous) descendant of the world’s first murderer, Cain, and apparent leader of the sinful hordes who attempt to battle for passage into the ark.  When the hordes fail, Tubal-cain selfishly manages to stowaway on the ark and try to manipulate Ham’s frustration to avenge himself on archnemesis Noah.7) Exploring the extent of Noah’s religious zeal, which flirts with the rationalization that he and his family, including loyal, passionate but sturdy wife Naameh (Jennifer Connelly, who reminds me a lot of Demi Moore), young Japheth, and even, shockingly, Ila’s newborn twins, must also die after saving the animals to fulfill the Creator’s mission.People may object to Aronofsky’s stylistic flourishes in Noah as being disrespectful to the Bible, unbelievable, or just plain silly.  I suppose arguments could be made for each of these viewpoints. Still, I feel that although “Noah” realizes and accepts that all Biblical/mythological stories relying on supernatural events can seem ridiculously hard to swallow, it ultimately adheres to the story’s spirit AND marvels and respects at all that the Creator (God) has made, and manages to be dynamic, rip-roaring, and surprising, too.P.S.:  My mother, who is a Greek Orthodox Christian, also approved of and enjoyed “Noah”.  Therefore, I respectfully recommend that “Noah” purists, religious or otherwise, relax and not be so resistant to the movie’s message.
summary: Tolkeinesque Elements Flesh Out a Well-Known But Sketchy Biblical Tale Into Both a Faithful and Entertaining Epic

reviewText: I saw Noah a week ago at my local theater, and am just now able to write a level headed review about it. See, Noah is that type of movie that you either absolutely love, or downright hate. Its the kind of movie that makes people fiercely defensive of their opinions, that sparks widespread controversy. This is rare, as movies nowadays seem to be pretty tailored to their target audience. Most of the controversy is centered around whether or not the film is biblical. As a Christian who has read the bible, I feel the need to point out that the bible is very vague concerning the story of Noah. God has the only speaking part, and the feelings and experiences of Noah and his family are not shared with us. If the film ONLY included the text as it was written, it would be about half an hour, and very impersonal. Darren Aronofsky adds additional material because if he didn't, there wouldn't be a film. There wouldn't even be any characters, other then names. Now, a lot of the controversy concerns what he added, mainly the bit about the fallen angels. People seem very confused about this, shortsightedly likening them to "Rock Transformers". The Nephilim, as they are called, are mentioned in the Bible, as well as in the Book of Enoch (Enoch was the great grandfather of Noah), which is a Jewish telling of the flood that is separate from the one in the Bible. They are also referred to in the Epic of Gilgamesh, which is an ancient historical and mythological text containing the story of the flood, also separate from the bible. If one considers for a moment that Darren Aronofksy came from a Jewish background, its easy to see where he would have gotten some of his content. Other characters from the Bible are featured, such as Tubal Cain (the leader of the 'wicked' humans in the film), as well as Methuselah, even though they aren't mentioned in the biblical story of the flood. If one considers that all of these people lived at the same time however, its not much of a stretch. You can have whatever opinion about the film that you want, I just thought it might be interesting for those of you who are confused as to what the Nephilim are, or who the "Yoda character" is. Now, considering the vagueness of the bible on the event of the flood, it is only reasonable that Darren Aronofsky would have to fill in some blanks, and he does take creative license with it. Of course a lot of it isn't in the bible, but it does not contradict or disrespect what is already there. I think it should be celebrated that the bible is so narratively complex, its mysteries so compelling, that a self professed Atheist would be moved to try and tell one of its stories. There is a lot of material in that book for compelling films, whether you believe it to be fact or fantasy.Of course, a lot of people will disagree with me, both on my opinions of the film and its source material. That is fine, I am just tired of reading negative and uneducated articles and reviews by people who refer to the Nephilim as "rock transformers", even by people who have admitted to not even seeing the film! Everyone is entitled to their own opinion, and some people will not like the liberties taken by the director. Its understandable. But as far as I am concerned, Noah is a beautiful, grim, powerfully compelling epic about the human capacity for wickedness and immorality, as well as love and mercy. The cinematography, art design, special effects, and music are uniformly brilliant. Russell Crowe brings a humanity and chilling focus to the character of Noah in one of his best performances, with Jennifer Connelly, Emma Watson, Ray Winstone, and Logan Lerman all turning in powerfully brazen work as well. The film is tense, brutal, spectacular, smart, emotionally involving and thought provoking. Love if or hate it, you cannot deny the importance and power of anything that has inspired so much debate and controversy. As entertainment, I loved it, as a story with compelling characters and themes, I loved it. If you enjoyed Braveheart or Lord of the Rings, and are willing to see Noah as a work of film rather than an advertisement for the Christian church, I think you will enjoy it too. And if you don't, that's okay. But at least see it and decide for yourself.

reviewText: The flood myth has been around a very long time.  Before the biblical tale, there was the tale of Gilgamesh in which a man named Utnapishtim was the hero of the flood tale.  Even this ancient Sumerian tale it is likely written down from a much older tale originating from the oral tradition, predating written language.  The story is well known, especially among the big three major religions, so how do you make a movie about the great flood, the most globally recognized story of Noah, and turn it into a movie worth watching?Herein lays the great problem.  The story is just too well known, globally, there are no real surprises in it.  The movie itself is well made, the acting is superb, and the story, while ancient, still feels fairly fresh.  So why was it so panned by so many people?  For most, it was simple, they expected a religious experience or a more religiously injected movie, and didn't get it.  For me, it was the shortcuts that were taken.Instead of a great wave, tsunami, tidal wave, etc., water explodes from the ground.  Instead of cutting from an existing forest, one was grown instantaneously from one seed supposedly from Eden.  Finally the addition of fallen stone covered angels all made these miracles seem a bit too contrived.  There were simply too many "miracles of convenience" to help add more wow factor than to actually add to a human drama of a family surviving a flood in a world of evil, especially in a world where "the creator" worked more through dreams and visions than actual miracles.The best parts of the movie are the human parts, and not the special effects.  Noah's conflict with the sons of Cain, the family's struggle to survive and follow Noah, his beliefs causing both a conflict with his family and his own morals all make for a compelling human drama.  This is not to say that the special effects were hack or all convenient, when done right they are done to perfection, but when used to produce shortcut miracles it seems a bit too showy.In short, one must approach the movie with an open mind, and a fresh eye, one must not re-read the story of Noah prior to watching this film, nor should one watch this movie with any religious preferences or expectations.  It is pure entertainment, and when it does it right and relies on the actors, it is done extremely well, but it is hard to hold the suspension of beliefs that this movie asks us to take when so many shortcuts are taken in the guise of miracles.
summary: The most non-religious biblical epic ever, which is not a bad thing.

reviewText: ...Christians -- or Bible purists of any kind -- would hate it for all its inconsistencies and evident blasphemous elements. (There is nothing particularly sacred about the Noah story so to tell it differently or embellish it is not blasphemous.) As a professing, practicing, born-again Christian, I figured way ahead of time that there wasn't going to be any more Biblical authenticity in this film than there was in "Life of Brian" and I might as well just toss out all my preconceived notions of what the "real" story of Noah should look and sound like. Thus, I wasn't disappointed; I sat down to watch a fantasy film with supernatural elements instead of a live-action Bible story.That said, I liked it. It was an interesting "end-of-the-world" scenario, no worse than many different end-of-the-world movies out there (well, it certainly WASN'T worse than "2012," which was so bad I was unable to finish it) and the acting and special effects were quite good. I don't mind Aronofsky's choice to make the Fallen Angels good instead of demonic, but for goodness' sake, rock creatures? Seriously??? As if sci-fi/fantasy films don't have enough rock creatures in them. But in the end I really LIKED what he did with them: God -- excuse me, "The Creator" -- FORGAVE them as they willingly died to save Noah and his family. What's even better is that, just before it happened, I realized that THAT is what was GOING to happen; I knew that when Samyaza was attacked and was being destroyed he would be forgiven and received back into Heaven. That was an unusual and unexpected illustration of the most fundamental truth of Christianity: God forgives.How do I feel that Aronofsky chose to use the term "The Creator" instead of just using God's name, "God?" I'm ambivalent. Aronofsky is not trying to convert nonbelievers into Catholics the way Mel Gibson was with "The Passion of the Christ" so it probably shouldn't matter to me so much... but I can't help it, it does just a bit. But again, I'm watching a fantasy film, not a Biblical film. I am going to choose to use the name "God," however, because that's what I know and believe in.Ray Winstone's part Tubal-Cain as Noah's primary antagonist was fine. I always like to see minor characters fleshed out and given personalities, but I'm undecided about how I feel about T-C's being a long-term stowaway. The film already had enough tension and conflict within the principle protagonists, but it did give Ham something more to do than brood. Ham's anger at his father for not saving the girl he'd picked out to be his girlfriend is understandable... or it would have been had he known her longer than 20 minutes. I certainly understand his adolescent angst that he would never, ever have sex if he didn't take matters into his own hands and go looking for it himself. I'm not a teenage boy, but I suspect they all feel that way at some point in their lives whether the world is getting ready to end or not. Was Ham so angry at Noah that he would hide T-C, with the understanding that T-C would eventually kill Noah? I don't really think Ham thought that far ahead. Teenagers generally don't. And Ham the character needed something to do to keep his situation uppermost in the minds of the audience.I did prefer, I think, the film's interpretation of Noah as a mortal, imperfect man instead of an ethereal, genteel, prophet-like super-human, which most Christians seem to prefer. And yet I enjoyed Methuselah as that very type of "magical" prophet. I mean, a guy who lives 1000 years has got to have some secret to long life; veganism can't be the answer to everything. Noah realizes and articulates a truth of the human condition: we are ALL corrupt. We are all born in sin and without redemption are condemned to die that way. None of us is born more innocent than others. He cries out to God, pleading, why did God give Noah this impossible task, the task of being the last of humanity, to even kill humans in order to remain true to that task? God is silent. Why? Because of course, Noah was wrong all along; God had never set that task before him at all. God was the one who sent the waters, God sealed the door of the ark, God destroyed mankind. God gave Noah love for his grandchildren, and when Noah acted on that love, that's when God responded with His blessings.And that, to me, is a pretty darn good Bible story.
